translated: whether or not the Buddhas arise. The characteristic of not-self is not evident without the arising of a Buddha; it becomes evident only with the arising of a Buddha. For there were powerful and mighty seers and wanderers, such as the teacher Sarabhangha, who were able to declare â€œImpermanent is all that is formed,â€ â€œPainful is all that is formed,â€ and â€œAll dhammas are not-self,â€ but they were unable to declare â€œAll dhammas are not-self.â€ For if they had been able to declare this to the assembly that had come to them, then the members of that assembly would have attained the paths and fruits. For the proclamation of the characteristic of not-self is not within the province of anyone else; it is within the province of the all-knowing Buddhas alone. Thus this characteristic of not-self is not evident. Therefore the Exalted One, in revealing the characteristic of not-self, revealed it either through the characteristic of impermanence or through the characteristic of pain or through both the characteristics of impermanence and pain. Here, however, it should be understood that he revealed it through the characteristics of impermanence and pain.

The four mental formations that are developed by one who has success in the act of exerting are called the footing for success consisting in the act of exerting. The two ideas, desire and concentration, enter into the footing for success consisting in the act of exerting as the aggregate of mental formations. And it is proper to say that they enter into the footing. Herein, energy is success. The four mental formations that are developed by one who has success in energy are called the footing for success consisting in energy. The two ideas, desire and concentration, enter into the footing for success consisting in energy as the aggregate of mental formations. And it is proper to say that they enter into the footing. The two ideas, desire and concentration, enter into the footing for success consisting in cognizance as the aggregate of mental formations. And it is proper to say that they enter into the footing. Herein, inquiry is success. The four mental formations that are developed by one who has success in inquiry are called the footing for success consisting in inquiry. The two ideas, desire and concentration, enter into the footing for success consisting in inquiry as the aggregate of mental formations. And it is proper to say that they enter into the footing.

translated: But there is nothing new here; it is only the elements already mentioned that are rearranged. How? The three things called zeal, consciousness, and endeavour are success and also a basis of success. The remaining associated things, the four aggregates, are a basis of success only. For these three things succeed only with the four aggregates associated with them, not without them. But the four associated aggregates are called success in the sense of succeeding, and a basis in the sense of a footing for that. Or alternatively, neither success nor a basis of success is a designation for anything else; they are a designation for the four associated aggregates only. The three things called energy, consciousness, and inquiry are success and also a basis of success. The remaining associated things, the four aggregates, are a basis of success only.

translated: In the description of â€œseeking gain with gainâ€ : seeking is seeking for, searching for, searching about, seeking about, seeking out, seeking after, seeking for the sake of, seeking by way of, seeking by means of. Again and again is seeking by way of. Giving alms food obtained from the beginning to young men of families here and there, and then going off after getting milk-rice at the end, is the story of the bhikkhu who did this that should be told here. Seeking, etc., are synonyms for seeking, seeking for, seeking about, and seeking out.
